Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Does Sequential Speciation Amplify Biodiversity across Trophic Levels?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will determine whether the creation of new species provides an opportunity for other organisms to take advantage of this and speciate in kind. In particular, the research will test whether when fruit flies of the genus Rhagoletis speciate by shifting and attacking new host plants, the parasitic wasps that attack the flies also speciate by following the flies and specializing on the new fly resources. The question is important for understanding nature because there are more species of plant eating insects like Rhagoletis and the parasites that attack them than any other types of life forms on Earth. Thus, understanding whether speciation has rippling effects through ecosystems to sequentially amplify the creation of new species has important implications for understanding the basis for biodiversity.

In addition to helping integrate science training, education, and research activities at the local, university, and international levels, the project also has practical benefits for U.S. agriculture. Rhagoletis flies are serious pests of apples, cherries, blueberries, and several other economic crops. The question of whether the fly?s parasitoids have formed new species, therefore, has important repercussions for developing effective integrated pest management strategies. Specifically, if different wasp species attack each fly, then biocontrol efforts would need to rear and release each of the wasps separately to control each of the fly pests. In contrast, if the wasps are all part of the same population, then a one-size-fits-all strategy focused on mass release of a single cultured wasp strain may succeed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New insect species can evolve after they begin to feed on new and different plants, and this may explain why there are so many plant-eating insect species on Earth. When an insect starts to feed on a new plant host, it can become isolated from populations of insects that still feed on the original plant host, which can lead to speciation in a manner analogous to when animal populations become isolated on different islands. Parasitic wasps, which lay their eggs in and then feed on the bodies of many plant-eating insects, are another extremely diverse animal group. The goal of this project was to test whether the origin of a new plant-eating insect species - after its shift to a new plant host - has also led to the origin of several new species of parasitic wasps that attack the plant-eating insect. We hypothesized that if parasitic wasps have followed the plant-eating insect to its new plant environment, then they may also have become isolated from ancestral parasitic wasp populations attacking hosts on other plants, and may also be splitting into new species. We used DNA sequences, behavioral data, field observations, and insect rearing data to show that three different parasitic wasp species are splitting into multiple new species due to their association with plant-feeding insects associated with new plant hosts. This is an exciting finding because it demonstrates the importance of ecological interactions in the origin of new species and may explain why parasitic wasps are among the most diverse group of animals alive today.

This research was also used to develop new tools for teaching evolution to undergraduate students who are not majoring in the sciences. Data collected in the course of the research was incorporated into classroom activities designed to teach topics relating to evolution, specifically animal speciation. These activities are now used regularly in two “active-learning” style classes at the University of Iowa. One of these activities has also been used several times at the University of Iowa as an example of how to design effective activities for active-learning classrooms. Graduate students involved with the research goals of this grant were involved in the development of teaching tools, an experience that has helped them to grow as both scientists and educators.
